The history

Writing, as defined by D. R. Olson is "a set of visible marks that are related, by convention, to some particular structural level of language" (Olson, D. R., ).

The writing creation also defines the beginning of history, a new science defined as "(the study of or a record of) past events considered together, especially events of a particular period, country, or subject" (Cambridge Dictionary, "history, noun", ). This pivotal development bifurcated our understanding of human existence into two categories: historical epochs, marked by written records, and prehistoric eras, predating written documentation (Cambridge Dictionary, "prehistory, noun", ).

Different writings

With our current understanding, it is widely acknowledged that the Sumerians pioneered a writing system (Gelb, I. J., ). However, recent evidence suggests a more nuanced perspective. Consider the Quipus, a system of knots potentially serving as a form of writing. The discovery of Quipus in Caral, Peru (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ), challenges the conventional narrative. These Quipus not only contained information akin to the records of later civilizations but also predate the colonial period. This discovery raises the possibility that the origins of writing may have emerged independently in South America (Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008).
Figure 1: Panel present at the archaeological site of Caral, ©ZonaArqueólogicaCaral, (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ). Photo taken on during a visit to the site.

Aside from Sumerian cuneiform and the potential inclusion of Quipus as a writing system, humans have devised various other writing systems (Olson, D. R., ). Among these systems are hieroglyphs, which emerged independently in different regions across the globe (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ), such as Egypt and Mesoamerica (Mora-Marín, D. F., ; Oudijk, Michel R,, ; Kettunen, Harri et al., ).
Figure 2: Altar, stele, and the largest hieroglyphic text at the Copan site (Instituto Hondureño de Antropologia e Historia, ). Photo taken on during a visit to the site.

Alphabet

The Phoenicians are commonly credited with the possible invention of the alphabet, which was later adopted by various civilizations (Olson, D. R. and Diringer, . David, ). However, alternative theories propose an Egyptian origin (Youtube - Linguriosa, ; Gardiner, A. H., ). Modern alphabets consist of characters that can be categorized into consonants (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ) and vowels (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ), facilitating the formation of words. In the Latin alphabet (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ) these groups can be represented as follows:
  • Consonants: b, c, d, f, g, h, j, k, l, m, n, p, q, r, s, t, v, w, x, y, z
  • Vowels: a, e, i, o, u

Telling stories

From the dawn of recorded history, humans have not only described factual events but also myths and legends. This duality becomes apparent when examining genealogy. While the earliest generations of our species were depicted in narratives, tracing family histories becomes challenging without written records. Interestingly, the Sumerians boasted of kings whose reigns spanned millennia (History Tracers, ; History Tracers, ), blurring the lines between fact and fiction. However, this phenomenon isn't confined to ancient history. A contemporary example can be found in the study of the Leme family, where Pedro Dias Paes (Leme) erroneously reported a paternal lineage (History Tracers, , Pedro Dias Paes (Leme)).

Historical inquiry serves as a tool to discern truth from myth, emphasizing the importance of analyzing all available documentation rather than cherry-picking evidence to support preconceived notions.

Subgroup

When investigating natural phenomena, researchers often face the challenge of working with limited samples, such as the inability to examine all available Hydrogen molecules (H2) (History Tracers (): Scientific Method). To overcome this limitation, scientists select smaller subsets, or subgroups, for study. Given that Hydrogen molecules (H2) consist of identical elements throughout the universe, findings from laboratory experiments or observations in one location are expected to hold true elsewhere.

Despite being ubiquitous in substances like water (H2O). Hydrogen molecules are invisible to the naked eye. To illustrate the concept of subgroups, consider the analogy of using the alphabet. The entire alphabet constitutes a group, but when we isolate and designate certain letters as vowels, we create a subgroup (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ). It is also possible to say that vowels are contained in the alphabet.

To complete the analogy between the alphabet and Hydrogen molecules, we must define the concept of equality. Just as we anticipate uniformity in Hydrogen molecules across different locations, we also expect consistency in the Latin alphabet and its subsets worldwide. Therefore, when someone writes the word "class", on this platform and another person in a different part of the world also writes "class", we have identical groups of consonants and vowels producing the same sound. Hence, we define equal groups as those containing identical elements.

Summarizing

The utilization of the alphabet likely marked a significant advancement in the tradition to memorize relationship.

In the realm of science, mathematics serves as a language through which we express relationships between groups using formulas, encapsulating our comprehension of nature in concise terms. For instance, let's consider how we could represent certain descriptions of the alphabet using mathematical notation:

  • Instead, of stating, "... when someone writes the word "class", on this platform and another person in a different part of the world also writes "class", we have identical groups ...", we could introduce a symbol to denote equality and comparison. If we designate the symbol '=' to represent equality, mathematically we would express this as: "class" = "class". Though simpler in form, this comparison yields an analogous conclusion to the original sentence.
  • Similarly, the assertion made earlier that vowels are contained in the alphabet, illustrating a subgroup within a larger group, can also be translated into mathematical language. When expressing that a smaller group is a subset of a larger one, we employ the symbol '⊂' to signify inclusion. Hence, we could write vowels ⊂ alphabet, signifying that vowels are a part of the alphabet.
While it's common in literature for groups to be depicted as sets, we have chosen to represent them solely as groups to enhance comprehension.
